IBM used to informally be an acronym that stood for "I've Been Moved". This was because at one time IBM had the proud reputation that they never fired people. replies.raw_content:
True, but at least we can export some of that inflation!  Officially, the U.S. legal money is the 'dollar' as partially defined in the Const. as a Spanish Milled Dollar and specifically defined in the Coinage Act of 1792 as a coin containing 416 grains of standard silver (i.e.  371.25 grains of pure silver mixed with copper).

The legal tender act made paper money legal tender throughout the entire District of Columbia (plus territories and other Federal lands as defined in Art. 1, Sec. 8, Cl. 17), but could not override the Art. 1, Sec. 10., Cl. 1 mandate that only gold and silver coin can be legal tender in the States.

Some what like folks to believe that the limit imposed by a1, s10, c1 applies to States but not the Federal Government, but (1) a careful reading of the legal tender decision claiming the right to make paper currency a legal tender relied on its original jurisdiction, which is exogenous to the States and (b) nowhere does the Const. grant legal tender power to the Fed. governments and it is one of the rights reserved to the States as guaranteed in the 10th amendment (N.B. the reason for limiting legal tender to base metals was to avoid runaway inflation.  To so limit the States while allowing some third power to make worthless paper a legal tender is so absurd as to believe those that proffer such an opinon must be stupid, or evil, or both).


See: 
https://www.usmint.gov/learn/history/historical-documents/coinage-act-of-april-2-1792

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_standards

https://www.archives.gov/founding-docs/constitution-transcript#1-10

replies.raw_content:
Coltan (short for columbite–tantalites and known industrially as tantalite) is a dull black metallic ore from which the elements niobium and tantalum are extracted. The niobium-dominant mineral in coltan is columbite (after niobium's original American name columbium), and the tantalum-dominant mineral is tantalite.[1]

Tantalum from coltan is used to manufacture tantalum capacitors which are used for mobile phones, personal computers, automotive electronics, and cameras.[2] Coltan mining[3][4] is widespread in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.[5][6][7]

comments.raw_content:
**Within 16 years of ratifying our Constitution in 1788, one of the Founding Fathers had already begun to understand the mistake they made in making the Judiciary independent.**
 
>- Nothing in the Constitution has given them [the federal judges] a right to decide for the Executive, more than to the Executive to decide for them. . . . 
>- The opinion which gives to the judges the right to decide what laws are constitutional and what not, not only for themselves, in their own sphere of action, but for the Legislature and Executive also in their spheres, would make the Judiciary a despotic branch.”  - **Thomas Jefferson** (Letter to Abigail Adams, September 11, 1804)

>- The original error [was in] establishing a judiciary independent of the nation,...” - **Thomas Jefferson** (Letter to John Wayles Eppes, 1807)

And in another 17 years, he seems to almost be in a panic about it.

>-  ... working like gravity by night and by day, gaining a little today and a little tomorrow, and advancing its [*the federal Judiciary*] noiseless step like a thief, over the field of jurisdiction, until all shall be usurped.”  - **Thomas Jefferson** (Letter to Charles Hammond, August 18, 1821)


http://www.robgagnon.net/JeffersonOnJudicialTyranny.htm

So if we don't gain some major technological insights re: computation, energy production, materials, etc... we could literally build a world on AI that's a house of cards and drive energy prices (which are already high) into the stratosphere.
